text: Patient: Most of stuff I had looked up, and so it’s okay now. Now, does this drug actually kill the cancer? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It does? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So it’s almost like a chemotherapy? Doctor: Well, it’s like a super hormone. That’s really what it is. It sits in the hormone pathway, so, it’ll kill it like that. Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer? Doctor: Yeah. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. text: Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful)

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - razor-sharp beam of radiation that targets one particular area and doesn’t really cause scattering of the x-rays to other areas. So it spares the normal tissues. Patient: Um Doctor: And we have people at this place that do that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um but I don’t want you to go into that therapy believing that this is also a potentially curative therapy. I think it could definitely cure the tumor in that one lymph node that we can see. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I kind of do think that a hormone therapy is sort of inevitable for you. Um the other question that you asked was about using chemotherapy. I presume that you’re asking whether that was either given by itself or maybe in combination with hormone therapy like as a clumped – double therapy. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. text: Patient: So we’re not going back to C__. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. I got that part of it. Family Member: Is any part of the change in the uh the lymph nodes, would that have anything to do with the testosterone or are you just saying that we’re not hormone sensitive so that probably did exacerbate the situation? Doctor: Well, we’ve been scanning you along the way. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you know when we were on enzalutamide we saw things getting bigger. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
